children.name: Paul’s Letters
children.subtitle: Paul affirms the resurrection in his earliest writings
children.details: Paul's epistles, particularly 1 Corinthians and Galatians, are among the earliest Christian writings and affirm the resurrection of Jesus as central to the faith. In 1 Corinthians 15, Paul emphasizes that the resurrection is of 'first importance' and lists post-resurrection appearances known to him and the early church.
whyItMatters: Earliest documentary evidence of resurrection belief.
Provides list of eyewitnesses, including himself.
Shows resurrection belief was central and widespread early on.

children.name: Early Creed
children.subtitle: Pre-Pauline formula affirming the resurrection
children.details: In 1 Corinthians 15:3–7, Paul cites a tradition that he 'received' and 'passed on,' widely recognized as a pre-Pauline creed. This creed includes Jesus' death, burial, resurrection, and post-resurrection appearances, indicating these beliefs were already established within a few years of the crucifixion.
whyItMatters: Very early formulation of resurrection belief.
Shows resurrection was not a later invention.
Embedded in oral tradition and early catechesis.

children.name: Sermon Summaries
children.subtitle: Public proclamations of the resurrection in Acts
children.details: The speeches in Acts, particularly those by Peter and Paul, repeatedly proclaim Jesus’ resurrection. While stylized by the author, they preserve early theological themes and rhetorical frameworks used in missionary preaching (kerygma).
whyItMatters: Reflect early resurrection preaching.
Echo eyewitness testimony.
Used to persuade diverse audiences (Jews and Gentiles).

children.name: Matthew
children.subtitle: Jewish perspective on the resurrection
children.details: Matthew emphasizes the resurrection with Jewish apologetic concern, addressing claims that the disciples stole the body. The narrative includes angelic appearance, the women’s testimony, and the Great Commission.
whyItMatters: Engages with competing Jewish explanations.
Affirms women as first witnesses.
Shows development of resurrection narrative.

children.name: Mark
children.subtitle: Earliest Gospel with resurrection account
children.details: Mark’s Gospel ends abruptly at 16:8 in the earliest manuscripts, with the women fleeing from the tomb in fear. Later additions (vv. 9–20) include resurrection appearances. The abrupt ending suggests emphasis on witness and response.
whyItMatters: Earliest extant Gospel.
Highlights fear and astonishment at resurrection.
Raises questions about textual transmission.

children.name: Luke–Acts
children.subtitle: Historically framed resurrection narrative
children.details: Luke provides detailed post-resurrection appearances (Emmaus, upper room) and links them to Acts, emphasizing continuity. Acts presents the resurrection as central to apostolic preaching.
whyItMatters: Combines theological and historical narrative.
Emphasizes physical resurrection.
Connects resurrection to mission of the church.

children.name: John
children.subtitle: Spiritual and personal resurrection accounts
children.details: John focuses on individual encounters with the risen Jesus (Mary Magdalene, Thomas, Peter). The narrative highlights recognition and belief and presents the resurrection as transformative.
whyItMatters: Emphasizes personal response to resurrection.
Affirms physical and spiritual aspects.
Reflects mature theological reflection.

children.name: Clement of Rome
children.subtitle: Affirms resurrection as part of Christian hope
children.details: Clement, writing from Rome to Corinth, uses the resurrection as a basis for hope and obedience. He appeals to the resurrection to encourage harmony and perseverance.
whyItMatters: Demonstrates post-apostolic continuity of belief.
Connects resurrection to ethical exhortation.
Reflects Roman church’s affirmation of resurrection.

children.name: Polycarp
children.subtitle: Martyr bishop affirms resurrection hope
children.details: Polycarp, a disciple of John, affirms belief in the resurrection in his letter to the Philippians. He exhorts them to stand firm in faith, grounded in the hope of resurrection and eternal life.
whyItMatters: Connects apostolic and second-generation witness.
Highlights pastoral use of resurrection.
Reflects enduring centrality of the resurrection.

children.name: Acts 4:1–22 — Peter and John before the Sanhedrin
children.details: Peter and John were arrested for healing a lame man and preaching about Jesus' resurrection. They affirmed that they must obey God rather than men, despite threats from the Jewish council.
whyItMatters: The public trial showed early opposition to resurrection preaching
The apostles were bold under threat
Both affirmed the same message of resurrection, showing a unity of witness

children.name: Acts 5:17–42 — Apostles Imprisoned and Flogged
children.details: All the apostles were imprisoned for preaching the resurrection. After an angel released them, they were brought before the Sanhedrin again, where Peter stated they were witnesses to these things. They were flogged and warned but left rejoicing.
whyItMatters: The apostles found joy in suffering
The angel's intervention underscored divine support
They persisted in teaching daily despite repeated threats

children.name: Acts 7:54–60 — The Martyrdom of Stephen
children.details: Stephen, a deacon, was stoned after delivering a bold defense. As he was being killed, he saw a vision of the risen Christ and prayed for his killers.
whyItMatters: The vision of the risen Christ reinforced belief even at death
Stephen's death marked the beginning of open persecution
His prayer for his killers paralleled Jesus' own crucifixion words

children.name: Acts 12 – James Martyred, Peter Imprisoned
children.details: The apostle James was executed by Herod Agrippa I, and Peter was arrested afterward, likely to face the same fate. The text emphasizes that apostolic witness to the risen Christ was costly from the beginning.
whyItMatters: The martyrdom of James, a direct eyewitness, and the imprisonment of Peter demonstrate the sincerity of their belief and the dangers they faced
The passage highlights that the apostles had no earthly incentive to preach and their persistence under threat only makes sense if they truly believed in the resurrection

children.name: Acts 12:1–5 — James Killed, Peter Imprisoned
children.details: King Herod executed James, making him the first of the Twelve to be martyred. Peter was then arrested and imprisoned but was later rescued by an angel.
whyItMatters: James's execution underscores the mortal risk of discipleship
Herod's actions show that resurrection preaching had real political consequences
Peter's imprisonment shows the ongoing danger to church leaders
